Overpriced beers, rude/judgemental/creepy patrons, and outdated song selections. 

Seriously, crowd. It's karaoke, not American Idol. Slow your roll.

Bartenders are always nice, DJ acts like he's a God for essentially knowing how to string together songs from similar genres.

Good for you, guy.

I live 2 blocks from this bar and thought I would forever be in heaven. However, although I tip well for my songs and drinks, I was told last night that people were "starting to bitch" because I had been up too many times. I sang twice alone, once with a friend. Another man sang at least 3 times alone.

I may not bring in groups of 6+ people, but I'm a paying customer and I bring in 1-2 people every few weeks. I will stick to singing into a hairbrush in my bedroom. This place blows.

Shout out to the girl in the glasses who sang Prince. You were fun.

EDIT: Shout out to some random girl from 2 months ago for sending me hate mail to edit my spelling. Doesn't make this review any less true. You da real MVP, 'Emily D.' (I spelled "the" wrong on purpose).
author: Kasena K.

description:
KJ on a power t(r)ip. seriously. i used to LOVE encore. i've been coming here regularly for the past 4 years and have had my last 4 birthday celebrations here because i loved it so much but what has happened? i'm sorry I didn't tip you mr. all powerful KJ but  that shouldn't give you the right to throw my song away. and also someone jacked my coat. thank goodness i was holding onto my purse. 

i guess it's time to start cruising the city for a better karaoke bar that won't throw out my song because i only had a 20$.

bartenders are great though. really nice and they don't skimp on the alcohol.
author: sara m.

description: Went in late Sunday night at around 11:00 p.m. zzzzzzzzno cover charge, just buy drinks to be able to sing!! ton of songs.
author: Dee C.

description:
I wasn't planning on going to Encore but after dinner at Cordon Bleu, it just seemed like a good idea. 

Encore is a large space and unlike other karaoke places they have plenty of books with music sorted by artist or title. 

There is a two drink minimum which doesn't seem to be strictly enforced. 

The crowd was fun and it is good for large groups. 

I think this place may be a new favorite of mine. 

It also seemed like they let you bring in outside food.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Came to Encore for my first time last night and thought it had a funny divey feel to it at first. That was until I went to sing a song and came back to an empty seat - my purse had been stolen and my friends hadn't noticed. The bartender said it happens often, so make sure to watch your stuff! 

Cheap drinks, decent karaoke, dirty ambiance, nice bartenders, but apparently attracts crap patrons that enjoy stealing while people sing. Sheesh, I knew my singing was bad, but not steal-my-purse bad!
author: Iman F.

description:
Good God, Almighty... this place almost took me right on out of the world of the living. It was everything my clean-freak self has ever feared: dirty, smelly, frightening denizens, and so grimy, not even the blessed state of complete inebriation could make you forget it.

I tried to be a good sport, really. I sat down on a chair (after finding one that wasn't visibly stained). I took pains to turn the pages of the songbook with a napkin, because they were so sticky, it actually took effort to do so. I tried tipping the bitchy KJ to play my songs only to get an earful of attitude back (point of order: I am not the one, son; read previous reviews to see why). I got into the swing of things by volunteering to entertain my friends/co-workers by singing a song.

And, then it happened.

The microphone touched my lips. THE MICROPHONE OF THIS FILTHY FILTHY PLACE TOUCHED MY LIPS!!! Vapors, auras, cling-clang sounds, vertigo... all happened at once. Rightfully horrified, I froze. My friends screamed out, "Run to the bathroom and wash your lips!" In shock, I did so... only to be slapped in the face by a smell so pungent, so unholy, the devil himself would have said, "Damn, man! Have you heard of Febreeze?" There's no way that bathroom could have been cleaned... ever. Pure, unadulterated STANK filled my nostrils as tears filled my eyes. But, I had to stay in there. I had to commit soap and water to my lips, lest the fungus of the unwashed find a new home in my sexy Angelina Jolie's.

After a vigorous washing, I was still convinced I had a social disease. My lovely co-worker, Laura, bought me a vodka. I think she thought by drinking it, I would get drunk enough to forget my trauma. Seeing that the glass was pure potato-stuff, I decided to soak my lips in it, with the hopes that the grain would kill the space invaders who were attacking me. Thanks to Encore Karaoke, I have stared into the face of the abyss and come back a changed man.
author: Johnny T.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night around 9ish.  

Rating is for the KJ - this guy has a bad attitude!  Was more focused on surfing the web then queuing you up.   You can buy his allegiance if you give him a dollar  (you get to wait for only 2 hours instead of 4 hours before getting on stage).    

Not coming back!
author: Katy W.

description: Totally depends on who else is in on the night you came in.  Wednesday night was basically slow but the clientele was positive.  No lines for singing and they played the basketball game in between lags () but I guess I can't blame them.  The bar tender was nice and GENEROUS with the pours.  Good experience, would love to come back with a group of my own friends!!
author: Sarah H.

description:
Have you ever walked innocently into a dark, seedy karaoke bar only to find an intense woman locking eyes with you while she belts out the most awful sounds you've heard eek out of a human? (longest run-on sentence of my life)

Well, I have. And you know what? It's what nightmares are made of. 

After my moment of recovery and a swift (necessary) drink order, I actually had a blast at Encore! And trust me, I had a rocky start as you can see. I'm sure that had more to do with the awesome group of people I was with rather than the actual bar itself. Honestly, the place was dead before we all walked in. Regardless, a great time was had, shame was set aside, and we rocked this joint!

I'm not much of a singer myself, but I heard the line was about an hour long to get your song played. That stinks, but if you tip the DJ he'd bump your pick up a few slots! The bartender was as nice as could be, but the bar was cash only. Good thing I had some on me! My drink was made swiftly and with a heavy-handed pour. I was a tender of the bar in my past life, so I do appreciate a knock-me-on-my-ass cocktail. The cutest part? He had do-it-yourself receipts for your drink order, if needed. Ha!

Just come to this place knowing that it's a dive bar, it's cash only and bringing your own fun is encouraged. If you're thinking Encore is going to be a great time with a bunch of tight-asses who don't enjoy liquid courage- you'll leave disturbed and bored. But if you dig that vibe, this is your kind of place. Also, be prepared to hear a few strange townies sprinkled into the karaoke mix. Just don't look them in the eye while their singing.... *shivers*
author: Cara L.

description:
Karaoke. Encore. Trouble. Encore. Hilarity ensues. 

It's a dive but I've ended quite a few nights here with some post-drinking song and merriment. Those nights are really awesome - a bonding ritual of sorts where colleagues keep secrets of the night buried and never to be spoken of again. 

I've also been here for karaoke fundraisers which in and of itself is a great idea! Nominate a friend to sing a song and put $(XX) on it. Better yet, pool your money together to make the pot bigger. Pick the most hillarious song you can think of. If said friend decides not to sing it, he matches the pot; half if he changes the song. It's all fun and for a good cause. 

The folks here are really nice and friendly so no matter if you're singing or not, you'll probably have a good time too. I know I do.
author: Jon L.

description:
Somehow or the other I've been to a lot of karaoke over the years, all around the country. So I know a thing or two about what's typical versus what's excellent.

This place was awful.

Like a good bartender, a good KJ is personable and reads the mood of the customer and crowd, earning tips because he or she has made the night more fun. They tailor the lineup for both maximum fairness and entertainment--each according to their personal system, of course, and one KJ may stringently disagree with another KJ's system.

There's nothing wrong with the location of Encore. It's a bar, it's tacky looking and feeling, it smells musty. The bartenders and the barback were great--friendly and funny and providing excellent service.  

The KJ the night I went (a tall heavyset man with little hair and a beard) was, however... He couldn't have looked more unhappy to be there. When I went to hand in my song choice he initially did not acknowledge me at all--to the point and for long enough that I was looking around to see if, maybe, there was a different place I was supposed to go, or a bowl I was supposed to drop it into...or something. Nope.

Then, after a few hours, I find out that if you want to sing here, you have to tip. It's not atypical for a KJ to be willing to bump you up in line if you tip; though I've met a number who think it's repugnant behavior. However, that's not what we're talking about, not that night at Encore.

Since the rest of my group had already had turns, although I wasn't in any hurry, I went to ask where I was on the list--figuring, sure, I'd have come up faster if I'd tipped, but surely I must be one the next few singers either way, since hours had passed--and the KJ pointed at a long one, saying, "The bottom."

I much prefer the system where you have to pay to request, because a tip is something you earn for providing better than usual service. Anything else is a bribe, and that's not how we do things in America--which probably sounds hyperbolic, but think about it. There are countries where bribery is typical and necessary to get anything accomplished. It's just not the culture in the US, and for many jobs it's either outright illegal or deeply unethical--you could get fired even over the appearance of it.

Not just in law or big business, either. Imagine if you went to the bar and ordered a beer. The bartender looks at you and says, "That's $5." It's a little weird that you'd have to pay before you get your beer, but...you pull out $5. He glances at it, but doesn't take it, and continues taking drink orders, bringing out drinks to several people. Eventually you ask, "Um, when can I buy my beer?" The bartender looks at you like you're a pest and replies, "When you tip me." You'd be unpleasantly surprised by this behavior, wouldn't you?

So, well, I was surprised the KJ was so extreme with his intention to never have my turn come up. I asked, "How is that even possible? I've been here for hours? Everyone who came in with me has sung?" Then he turns on the "charm", becoming positively polysyllabic as he says, "They probably paid to get ahead. If you pay, too, I'll see what I can do."

You can imagine that I was in no mood to pay. What had the KJ done to earn a tip? Paying him was no guarantee, either. What if I didn't tip as much as he wanted? Or someone else tipped him more after me?

I was annoyed, but while I like singing at karaoke, it's not the reason I enjoy it. I had some friends there, and while it wasn't the best crowd I've seen at karaoke (on the best nights, in my opinion, everyone's happy and supportive and participates and strangers come to feel a little like friends) lots of people seemed to be having a good time, and it's nice to be around people having a good time.

I go back, therefore, to the bar to enjoy others' enjoyment and chat with my friends and the bartenders. Another hour passes and the KJ walks by. When he sees me, he mimes shock. He says to me, extremely sarcastically, "You're still here? Why? YOU'RE not singing."

Let's think about this for a moment. I imagine the bar is the more profitable part of the establishment for the owners of Encore. The karaoke is a draw, but not a money maker. Their KJ fully expected his treatment of me to provoke me to leave--possibly with my friends--and had no issue with that at all.

When it turned out he hadn't driven me off, and that I was still putting money in the pockets of the people who pay him (just not, directly, in HIS pockets) he had no qualms about taunting me to my face...right in front of his coworkers.

I honestly can't imagine why Encore employs him. In addition to being a jerk who is willing to drive off their customers, he didn't give me the impression of being a good KJ in any way.
author: Reese H.

description: Rudest karaoke host I've experienced anywhere I've done karaoke in the u.s.  rude when I handed him our ticket. Waited two and a half hours then my friend went up and he said "you don't get up here until you tip first."  then we realized why we never get called  up there and I'm visiting from out of town. And his song tracks are the worst versions on the market. Nice bartenders but worst karaoke ever.
author: Kari K.

description: Party down Fridays at encore! Happy hour is amazing. It's cheap drinks and a KJ with an amazing library! I think his name is lee and he is playing the jams! I been to the last 2 and the crowd was feelin my songs and the drinks were amazing! Encore u deserve five stars best karaoke bar in town!
author: Adam L.

description:
This place is billed as a karaoke bar, but in fact, it's a surgery center for injured hippos. No anesthetic is used.

If you are human, and especially if you have any sense of pitch or respect for your ears at all, you will find yourself running screaming from the general area just from walking past the place, much less thinking of going in to torture yourself. How they find their "singers" is something I just don't want to know about.

I really feel sorry for the owners of neighboring businesses, which tend to be empty most of the time, probably due to the offensive noise.
author: Sue E.

description:
I had a good time here and the staff were pretty nice.  The song list was amazing, and I manged to get up thrice for my requests on a busy night.  Hint: Tip your KJ.

Like many SF night spots, cash is required.  The drinks are not cheap, so plan on hitting the ATM before putting in your song request.
author: Sam G.

description:
Encore Karaoke is a packed house on Friday nights. I got there around midnight, and the song list was already filled up until last call. Luckily, the drinks were stiff and the bartenders were generous, so we enjoyed a few painful duets (and a few nice solos) until last call at 1:30am. 

Lessons learned: come early, drink your courage quickly, and if you pick 'American Pie', you and your friends are stage-hogging jerks.
author: Kevin B.

description:
First of all, I am surprised that I even checked-in here. This was, after all, the night that began with too much wine at Barbacco, got going with an epic fail compilation of falls (first in a sink-hole, then out of a cab), spun my head around with punch from Rickhouse, then plunked me down right in the middle of Encore.

The rapid succession of various drinking establishments (or places where alcohol is vaguely served) that led to this karaoke experience is telling. I was here with Jamie D, who I must quote:
"I love karaoke. I love dive bars. Karaoke + Dive bar = Encore.

Yes, this place is dirty. Yes, this place is cash only (or so I'm told. I actually didn't buy my beverages while there). Yes, there's a wait for karaoke. But this second floor totally seedy bar is the perfect spot for belting out Whitney Houston without any shame."

What I do remember about this place is the utter lack of propriety that anyone in attendance has left by the time they walk through the doors. I don't think I wore shoes the entire time I was there, I absolutely sang backup/ danced around in the "performance area" with people I had never seen in my life, and I laughed so hard I cried.

For a late night spout of drunken team-bonding, Encore's the spot. For anyone not ok with a seedy dive bar scene and sticky floors, maybe go somewhere else. Either way, take it from me: wear shoes. I know that God made dirt, so dirt don't hurt, but Encore dirt just might.
author: Alden C.

description:
If you like "greasing" the k.j. in order to perform, then this is the place for you! Unfortunately, I don't believe in forking over money to some guy who looks like he just got out of a correctional facility in order to sing. When I was at Encore on Friday night, I watched the same people go up and sing over and over again. The place wasn't all that busy, so I approached the k.j. after waiting for 45 minutes to be called up. The k.j. tells me that it's going to be another 45 minutes before I'm up. Really? A grand total of an hour and a half of waiting? When I asked if $20 would bump me up the list, he eagerly said that it would. I walked away disgusted with no intention of bringing Mr. Blood In, Blood Out any money. I hung out with some friends for a bit longer and eventually left after not being called up once after residing in the bar for over 2 hours. 

This place really is the worst. Even Silver Cloud, which also sucks, is better than this dump. Encore's only redeeming quality is that the bartenders are friendly and make exceptionally strong drinks. Unfortunately, I didn't come for the drinks; I came to sing. I think I'll stick to the Mint moving forward...
author: Jen S.

description:
I love karaoke. I love dive bars. Karaoke + Dive bar = Encore.

Yes, this place is dirty. Yes, this place is cash only (or so I'm told. I actually didn't buy my beverages while there). Yes, there's a wait for karaoke. But this second floor totally seedy bar is the perfect spot for belting out Whitney Houston without any shame.

I was there on a Monday night and the wait for karaoke wasn't too awfully long.  And to make it even better, about halfway through our visit only a handfull of people were left vying for the mic. What did that mean? Oh, just more time for us to take center stage and show off our performing prowess (or lack thereof, as the case may be). 

The biggest challenge of karaoke, in my opinion, is always the song choice. On this particular visit, various people in our group rocked renditions of Sinead O'Connor, O-Town, Whitney Houston, and the Spice Girls, to name a few. 

By the end of the night everyone was a backup singer and all inhibitions had disappeared. That, to me, is the sign of a successful karaoke night.
author: Jamie D.

description:
The BEST karaoke dive bar in the city!

Yes people, it IS a dive bar. What the hell did you expect? The funny thing is, that's what I LOVE the most about it!  

It's a dive bar that has the most amazing collection of karaoke songs I've ever seen, and its not pretentious and scary to get up on stage.  EVERYONE who goes up to sing is freakin awesome because they don't give a f*ck. They just sing it loud and proud, and everyone is drunk and has a ball. THAT's how karaoke should be done.

Song books:
They actually have different versions of the song lists. One of them is organized BY SONG. But there are others that are organized BY ARTIST. I've seen it. You just have to find it first, or borrow it from another table.  There is also a song list for recently released pop songs if you're feelin like a little Lady Gaga, etc.

So if you're lookin to do a little karaoke, forget the private rooms.  Step up to the plate and sing for an audience! It's 10x more fun, and you can have a dance posse behind you since the "stage" is so big!
author: Gina R.

description:
I love any place that allows you to sing your heart out any day of the week. You don't need to keep up with a weekly calendar to determine whether or not you can sing your troubles away because Encore is a dedicated karaoke bar/lounge. That being said, it still left me wanting more. 

The song books are big and have plenty of songs to choose from, but we weren't able to find some songs that you would expect a place like this to have. They didn't have Johnny Cash's "Walk the Line". Really?! They were also missing "Juicy" by B.I.G. Under the first section that is supposed to be the newly released songs they had songs from Britney Spears that are at least three years old. Come on, update that ish! Also, the songs can be difficult to search for because they are sorted alphabetically by song and not by artist. Heaven forbid you have to look up a song that starts with "the" or a contraction. 

I also felt like the sound isn't set up properly. The stage area is too far from the seating area so if you're sitting down and waiting for your song you can't hear the person sing over all the people talking. Then, when you're singing you can't hear yourself sing and you end up being all off and singing extra loud and then you lose your voice by the time you're done with "Big Poppa", or maybe that's just me.

Pro tip: You MUST tip the KJ if you want to get your song in within a reasonable time. This is definitely not first come, first serve.
author: Daisy S.

description: Went back, KJ was rude once again. :( Thought he was God and played song after song for another group of people while ignoring us. Won't return.
author: Dawn S.

description:
Oh karaoke! How I hate to love thee! But, I do really love heading out to a karaoke bar, especially with a large group of people that have been drinking and are ready to regale me with Dolly Parton, Blackstreet, Brittney Spears, Abba, and much much more.

Encore, I apologize to your regular clientele for over-running your dark divey space, occupying every last table, and hogging the stage with all of our renditions of popular songs, both good and bad. But, I thank you profusely for allowing us to engage in said antics and having enough room for us to do so.

This bar is definitely questionable in the clean department, but I wasn't scared. They are cash only, but I saw a welcoming ATM in the house. And best of all, the bartender was friendly and served up stiff drinks, which is just what a crowd needs to fully enjoy a night behind the mic.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
divey karaoke bar is ok. 

Crowd is very mixed. Drinks are cheap so that's a good thing. The selection of songs is pretty good. Came here on a Thurs night around 8pm and it was pretty dead. No karaoke was going on till about 9 or 10pm. There's no judging here as everyone will cheer you on or ignore you when you go up to sing. I mean ignore as in they will carry on with their conversations or stare at their phones while you sing. There's no booing or anything. There are some really great singers that show up here that make it a little intimidating for us tone deaf people that want to shout out our favorite songs at the top of our lungs. 

All in all, encore is a solid spot for cheap drinks and good times with stage karaoke but for karaoke alone, I would prefer to go somewhere else.
author: Christine W.

description:
If you want to have a fun night out singing kereokee, don't come here!!!

We put our names up and after like 2 hrs and they didn't play our song we were told that if u didn't tip at least $10. Than your not getting up to sing!!!

I'm all set with having to tip someone to do there job, when they don't even do there job!!!!

Cans!!!!
author: Keith L.

description:
To each is own, but I don't understand karaoke culture sometimes. I mean, do some of the die-hards think they're going to run into Clive Davis at a dive bar while reciting the lyrics to a three-decades old Bonnie Taylor song and score a record deal? I sure as hell don't, but I think some of the regulars at Encore do.

Been here on two occasions, and each time, the room is filled with the biggest bunch of wankers ever. Folks who take life and Queen's Bohemian Rhapsody a little too seriously. The first time I was here, I actually saw a guy doing vocal exercises outside by the staircases that lead into the front door. Would have been hilarious if he were just screwing around... but this guy was serious. I suppose I can't knock the dude for really trying to steal the show, but it's not the kind of karaoke I like to engage in.

For me, karaoke is all about having fun and fucking around. I'm a terrible singer, but at least I have a good time while banging out classics like 'You Outta Know' and 'Chocolate Salty Balls.' Sadly, because I'm not on the professional karaoke circuit, I've never been well-received at this place. 

Oh well.

The bar itself is pretty cool. Bartenders are nice, the KJ is swell enough and will get your songs on as quick as he can... and the volume rises as the night grows older. If you're there at 7:00pm, the output is going to be much heavier a few hours later at 10:00pm. They also have plenty of seating, so large groups can probably always find a table. BUT, if you want some lighthearted karaoke fun... Mint or Playground might be better options.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Let me begin by saying that I have been a long time and loyal customer of Encore. I love Karaoke, it's one of my favorite things to do on a night out, and Encore was my favorite spot to do it. However, after this weekend I will not be back.... ever. And I don't think you should visit  either. 

There was some confusion between a friend of mine and the bar tender over twenty dollars. He has written a review as well and I recommend you read his first hand account. I did not actually see the altercation or much of the aftermath that followed. What I do know is that many of my friends left the bar having been chocked, punched or pushed by the bouncers. My friend was trying to talk about what had happened and the bouncers/bartender decided it was appropriate to put their hands on him. The staff's actions were not only inappropriate but illegal. 

It hurts my heart to write this, I loved this place and will be mourning the loss, but it's just not a safe place. If my friend, who is soft spoken and well mannered, can provoke violence from the staff I can only conclude that anyone could provoke violence from them. I'm not willing to risk my safety for a good song selection and cheep drinks.


Go to The Mint. They've got a Great song book too.
author: Missy M.

description:
Hmmm, almost gave this place 2 stars. But then I thought, it was a pretty good time.  Screens are small and volume doesn't feel like it fills up the room.  Really Grundgy.  

But there are pluses.  The positioning of the main screen is right in the middle of the dance floor, so you feel the energy of people dancing around you and supporting you.  There is a pool table so singing isn't the only thing to do.  The DJ is pretty entertaining with his commentary.  

Although Mint has a better set up with its stage and bigger screens, Encore provides a more entertaining place with a roomier feel and more things to do.
author: Veasna H.

description:
I've been to every 'aoke bar in SF and this is probably my favorite. The people there are always lively and cool, the equipment is good, and the song list is extensive. It is my go-to place. However, it does have a couple issues: 1. The place is a bit run down, which doesn't necesarily bother me. 2. It gets super crowded on Friday/Saturday nights.

My advice is to get there early or hit up on weeknights if you don't want to wait 3-4 hours for your song...
author: Alex H.

description:
So Encore is a lot of fun. Diverse song selection and fun inside! There are some musical kiddos that come and sing here. You sing so well, you make me feel bad singing Neil Diamond off tune! It's not a pretentious crowd and people generally are here to have a good time.

KJ, Mr. DJ, you need to STOP allowing your friends to sing their tunes first. It's called go in order, follow the numbers, two after one, three after two you ignoramus! Minus tjree stars for you alone. You boil my blood! And also it's a bit grimey in there... reminds me of the MUNI.
author: Rosa L.

description:
The drinks are stiff, the KJ is grumpy, and the place is a dive. That can make for a fun night if you roll in and take over a place with a huge group of friends on an otherwise dead Monday night, but I wouldn't be excited to swerve in on a more crowded night because I suspect the KJ would put the regulars ahead of us in line, always. Oh well. It's better than the Mint in terms of the folks not being über serious about their crappy Karaoke skillz, but whatever. 

I'm sure I'll be back for more fernet shots and god-awful renditions of Bell Biv Devoe's "Poison".
author: Don B.

description:
Everyone who works at Encore is a sweetheart. The people really make this place, but I also love that it's big enough for large groups and has a great song selection. Here are a few universal karaoke rules that will help you have fun and get great service at Encore or any karaoke bar:

1. Tip, tip, tip. Tipping is a social contract from which you benefit as a customer. If you can't afford to tip, drink at home. Don't forget your KJ! $1 or more per song is customary; just don't expect to be bumped up in the rotation for a big tip.

2. Put in one song request at a time, even if one of them is a duet. It's confusing/annoying for KJ's when you put in multiple song requests. Wait until you sing to put in your next request. 

3. Remember that karaoke bars are not run as non profits. If you want to sing, buy at least two drinks, even if they are non alcoholic. Do not bring in your own booze.

4. Never try to join in on a stranger's song without express permission.

5. Don't go in the KJ booth or behind the bar. 

6. Treat the staff and fellow patrons with respect.
author: Heather C.

description:
The good: They have CIDER!!!!  TONS of songs to choose from!  The floor for the karaoke was very large.  The bartender was uber nice!!

The bad: cash only, seemed to be a dive bar/ mini venue that was not kept up with cleanliness so they turned it into a dive, karaoke lounge.  Didn't smell to great, glad there were amazing people in my group to keep me entertained!!  The stage should have been up at least 2 inches so those in the back could experience the amazing dance moves!

Overall, somewhat ok if you are expecting a dive bar that is not clean.
author: Colleen B.

description: I feel bad giving this place 2 stars because a good friend of mine has dragged us here at least half a dozen times for karaoke night.  But Encore is pretty boring even on crowded nights.  People here aren't as flamboyant or have as snappy dance moves as the crowd at Mint, Pandora or Festa.  The songbook is dated and facilities (carpet, pool table bathrooms) are in really bad shape, even for a dive joint.  My general sentiment when I'm here can be encapsulated in "ew".
author: Letitia L.

description:
3.5 stars...not quite 4. 

Decent place to come sing your heart out up on stage with close friends...and the rest of the bar of course. Their accoustics aren't quite up to par as you can barely hear the person singing once the bar starts to fill up. Which I suppose isn't necessarily a bad thing. They didn't seem to have a very up to date song book to choose from, plenty of classics but nothing terribly new.

If you're a serious karkaoke singer come early and get your songs in to the DJ right away. If you're going because you're on your 3rd shot of tequila and have decided this is the best idea since sliced bread show up around 10ish, put your song request in, and you have about a 50/50 chance of getting up on stage...but you'll have a hell of a time while your there either way.

Happy Hour every day: 3pm-7pm 
($3.50 well drinks and $2.50 domestic beer)
Karaoke-8pm-2am

p.s. cash only!
author: Kristy M.

description: WOW did we have fun at this bar! We had some friends in town from Melbourne, Australia and they told us they wanted to Karaoke.  We had a couple of choices, but this place seemed like it would best fit our needs.  It was Friday night and we arrived around 10PM. We easily found a table to park ourselves and begin searching through the huge books with almost everything you could think of singing.  Everyone was so friendly there, within 20 minutes not only did we make new friends, they bought us drinks and we started singing together.  What I loved most about this place is that people chose the best karaoke songs, so the whole bar would erupt in song and dance.  Very rarely did people do the self-indulgent ballads that bore the crap out of you.  I really appreciate that, being a karaoke connoisseur.  The KJ was nice enough, you needed to tip to get your song played but hey it's SF and this place is expensive.  The bar prices were reasonable and the facilities clean.  I would wholeheartedly recommend this place for a night of karaoke!
author: Jen B.

description:
At the end of the day, people judge karaoke on two main factors:

1.) When the f*ck am I gonna sing?
2.) Do they have my f*cking song?

The good news that is that, for the most part, Encore is pretty good about managing your songs and/or your party (tip accordingly, however), and will most likely have your song as long as you're not looking for the hottest track to come out on the radio this month. The bad news is that if you're a diva, it'd probably serve you best to stay away.

Decor in this place is pretty sparse, but its divey atmosphere lends it some charm that others places I've been to in the city just don't have. The regulars are all great characters and very rarely will you find those pretentious folks you'd expect to show up and make you hate karaoke. All of these people work 9-5 to feel like a rock star for five minutes, so the support everyone gets after songs is pretty amazing. With the stage as big as it is, don't be surprised if people start an impromptu dance crew behind you or decide to be your back-up singers. 

And if you're here on a Friday or Saturday night? Brace yourselves; bros and "woo girls" are coming. 

Drink-wise, the bar's pretty good with cheap drinks that aren't watered down, but it being cash-only might disappoint a few folks. However, the people behind the bar, especially folks like Matty and Kenny, are some of the coolest and nicest people to get you drunk on a weekend.

Other quick-hits:

(+): Great atmosphere, not intimidating in the slightest. Good for newcomers. Great selection of songs.

(-): Place has its occasional seedy characters, so always make sure people are watching your bags. Bathrooms are cramped, particularly for men.
author: Marc A.

description:
Dark, mysterious, a bit ghetto, but I guess it will do.  Been here twice already.  Once for a b-day and once for Santacon.  Both times, I didn't really want to order a drink.  Perhaps I feel that its so dark, I wonder how clean it is.  Just looking at the quality if furniture, decor and bartender, you question.  Question what's in the dark. . .has the carpet been vacuumed, have the tables been wiped,. and how old are these karaoke books.  And why are they sticky?

You put your song selection on a ticket and drop it in a basket by the DJ.  Tip him and you're song may come on sooner.  . . . but still, its dark, mysterious, a bit ghetto. . . and you even get a scary bouncer too.  Hmm, its welcoming (as I say with chills down my spine).
author: Janice F.

description:
A great Karaoke spot! Feels like a real dive bar. Very dim, and by 9pm, very crowded. I love that the stage is the same level as the rest of the place (no extra anxiety from looking down to the crowd from a high stage). Sing alone, or sing with a large group (for one song, we almost filled up the entire stage with everyone singing and dancing.
Mixed drinks and beer variety is your standard fare. Nothing special really.
Love the pool table in the corner, and the two levels of table seating. And allowing us to bring outside food in (pizzas), a big plus. I never get sick of this place.
author: Ron Z.

description:
This is--hands down, the dirtiest establishment I have ever set foot in.

Firstly, I don't think this place has ever been cleaned. Absolutely everything from the nasty carpet to the cracked bar stools seemed to be brewing with germs. I couldn't even touch the Karaoke menu because the cellophane-wrapped pages were literally brown. 

General nastiness aside, the bartender was completely rude to me. I was with my boyfriend and his friend, and he decided to only card me--despite the fact that I was just having a ginger ale. Mildly understandable. I hand him my passport and he spent a very awkward 45 seconds staring at my information. Then said, "You need a valid id." Um, excuse me? After telling him that a passport is a valid form of identification, he chastised me for having an attitude, tossed my passport back in my direction and walked away. 

The only thing this karaoke bar could've possibly done to redeem itself would have been to have decent customer service.  Fail.
author: Tiana B.

description: My friend and I did an experiment- we both put in a song at the same time- she gave him $10, I did not. As we suspected, he called her song and never called mine! I went back up and asked him, and he said "if you had wanted to sing you should've tipped me like your friend did" so, word to the wise, if you want to sing at encore on a busy night, you'll need to also bribe the DJ, or your song goes right in the trash!
author: Lindsay G.

description:
I like this place, and it's the best karaoke place in town. that doesn't necessarily say much, since the competition is awful, but it still says something.

Best bet is to get there early on a weeknight. Weekends after 9:30pm can be a bit filled with drunken douche bags from the Marina, etc, etc but generally the crowds are cool enough. 

Vu is a really great bartender and KJ - and in general the KJs are better now than they were a few years back.

Drinks are reasonable enough with decent pours. 

Pretty good song list too. 

Better than The Mint!
author: Lalita K.

description:
Trying to impress an out of town karaoke expert, we went to Encore. This was the second time I tried to impress her with SF's karaoke culture; the last time Encore left a horrible impression. Well they lived up to their name by doing it again.

Encore is not a karaoke lounge, it is a little fiefdom ruled by amateur karaoke jocks. First, be upfront about tipping prior to singing being mandatory. That's cool. Once the KJ said a 50 dollar tip would get a name called immediately. This most recent time we were told that a 20 dollar tip would get a person's name called right away. I felt like we were being extorted. We didn't care about getting called first, just getting called sooner than the three hour wait that it took would have been enough. There were several people who sang over and over. New people were _rarely_ called up. New people were called hours later when the bar was clearing out.

Encore is a nasty dive (the word "dive" is too good for this place) with grouchy door security, expensive beer and karaoke singing comes at a huge price.

Avoid Encore and go over to Silver Cloud where karaoke singing is more democratic. Next time, we'll go over to Japantown and rent a karaoke room and run the show ourselves --- fairly.

I'm not ever going back to Encore.
author: Jen A.

description:
Encore made me feel like a whore. It was our first date and they took my karaoke virginity, I feel so dirty.

It probably had something to do with the booze or a karaoke version of a roofie, but for the first time I went up to the stage myself instead of just sitting back and listening. For the record, I probably picked the worst first song of all time as it was over six minutes long.... nothing like being hammered and feeling like you've been up there for 35 minutes. But I enjoy the 1979 Sugarhill Gang hit "Rappers Delight" so that's what I did. It wasn't the smoothest ride, but thanks to the crowd and the scene I really didn't care. Next time it's gonna be "Pony" by Ginuwine, just wait.

The bartender, bless his heart, was amazing. I was drinking Glenlivet like it was going out of style and my partner in crime for the eve was drinking Belve mixers. She too was a karaoke virgin yet somehow knocked "Fever" by Peggy Lee out of the park. Good times.

But back to the 'tender of the night. I go up for round two, and I hear him  say "wanna do a shot". "What?" I ask, because generally bartenders don't toss out random shots to non-regulars. He took my question to mean "Of what?" and said whatever I want. Pffff, whatever you want homie, if it's free I'm down. So tequila it is.

It comes time for round four and dejavu, "wanna do a shot" from the friendly gent behind the counter. No more questions from me, just a straight forward "Of course". 

I'm now deep in the world of scotch whiskey and free tequila shots when round five rears it's head. Somehow a Glenlevit on the rocks and a Belve mixer came to $8 total. Anyone who ever buys these two liquid delights knows that is a freakishly low total. In other words thank you bartender, you're my hero.

Way too much fun, I can't wait to go back. Sure, Japantown will have some gems I'm sure, but the pairing of friendly regulars here in combination with the Jesus of bartenders leads me to believe I'll be flexing my new found rapping skills here more often. A few more nights like this one and I'll be a drunken karaoke bar fly in no time.
author: Justin N.

description: My friends and I went here on 5-19-14 10:15pm'sh, after we left deluxe club.  I ordered two heinenken $6 each (moderately priced).  Fairly good sound system, ample song list.  All of us sang one song each, I know that if it's Friday/Saturday, forget it, I'm not going to wait too long.
author: Jer W.

description: awful. tipped& didn't get a song in on a Wednesday. bartender begged for extra tips. boo!
author: Alex G.

description:
Okay, I've heard great things about this place, and how fun it is. I came on a not so busy night, and I can imagine this place is probably a fun place when crowded, and to be honest, it was fun even when not so crowded. That's not my reasoning for the poor review... fun is not what this place lacks.

Immediately when walking into this place it smelled like crap. It took me about half an hour to get used to the old building smell. It smelled like a damp, dirty people cave. The place was dim inside, but not too dim to the point where I couldn't see the terrible carpeting, and dusty decor. Okay, it's a karaoke bar, I know. I wasn't expecting leather couches and shiny hardwood floors. But come on, Silver Cloud is even WAY cleaner than this place. And don't even get me started on the one bathroom they have in the back. Probably the most disgusting bathroom I have ever seen, I'm not even kidding.

To boot, the DJ was a huge a-hole. "Remember to pay me," and "Don't forget to tip your DJ" were regular phrases heard from the microphone. How annoying. It takes you about a millisecond to press the play button. I understand tipping if you go up there a few times, but on a dead night I don't think it's necessary. My friend who was with me said that she went there once and because she didn't give the DJ enough money he wouldn't play her song. Excuse me, dude, they are tips. If you have a problem with your paycheck, speak to your boss, not us. And what was he expecting? A $10 bill? What a jerk-off.

I'll come here if there are a group of friends meeting here, but somehow I highly doubt that will happen.

A plus: they have an amazing song selection (way better than Silver Cloud). Maybe it's worth the smell, a-hole DJ, and a few bucks to get the song you really want to sing? You decide.
author: Ashley D.

description:
FUCK this place!  My friend was harassed by some creepy guys she met there who pushed her hard against a wall outside after they left. She has bruises all over her back now, almost a week later.  My other friend jumped in and tried to get everyone to calm down and he got jumped by the creep and his friends!  Trust me, he is not a fighter, these bullies were looking to start shit.  Meanwhile my purse was stolen and the asshat that stole it took my phone and sent inappropriate photos to everyone  in my contacts list.  He made me moon my dad (which ok, is kind of funny, but only if I do it!)!!!  I'm so FUCKING PISSED!  

And by the way, our group got there at 11 and by that time the dj/karaoke guy  said the   song list was full.  The place was half empty, and we sat there till last call waiting for our songs to come up.  We were only able to get one of them to play because we tipped the dj a 5.  Ridiculous. I've never had to tip extra to get my song to come up at a karaoke place.  I've lived in the city for 5 years, and this is the worst night I have ever had here.
author: Elena M.

description:
This is the worst karaoke experience I've ever had. I thought about writing as soon as I got home on Saturday night, but thought better of it.  I've seen more than my share of karaoke bars, and am no stranger to dives, or kitschy places where one has to roll with the punches.  

Be prepared to sit for 3 hours and not sing once.  Why? Because at Encore you have to pay to sing. I'm familiar with paying to sing multiple times, but when you arrive and are told 3 hours later that you're still 10 songs away...well, you get where I'm going.  In order to sing, be prepared to drop 15-20 dollars per song.  

The karaoke DJ was unfriendly, rude, and generally the worst karaoke dj i've ever seen.  I get that you're there to get paid, but sheesh.  I have friends that love and swear by this place, but I don't get why anyone would want to waste a night here. Real talk.
author: Kia S.

description:
Went on a weekday so the bar was slow. We did get our drinks fast and we got up and sang a few times. I do agree with everyone that the bar could use some cleaning...

oh and dont try to go up and sing with someone else (spontaneously) because you will get "escorted" off the stage by the bartender...lol. Lame.

Its a shame because it is a great stage.
author: Lidia Z.

description:
Why are there so many cash only places in San Francisco? Or did I just get dragged to every spot in the city that ONLY accept cash? Either way, it's kind of annoying.

What's NOT annoying is karaoke with a fun group of peeps. Our group basically took over the bar at Encore and rocked da house! OK, that was lame, but we really did have a good time. 

Yes, the KJ will play your songs sooner if you tip him. Makes sense. Yes, they have a good selection of songs. And yes, we stayed here way past our welcome, but who cares? 

Good times had by all!
author: Abby S.

description: I would vote zero stars if I could have. The Karaoke jockey is absolutely deplorable. You will only get on the karaoke song list rotation if you tip him. This is extortion. The good people of San Francisco, California, and all visitors do not deserve to be treated this way. This is against karaoke etiquette. We come to a bar that promotes karaoke to sing and have fun. The bar pays the individual karaoke jockeys an hourly fee to provide entertainment to its guests. There is no reason the guests should have to pay both the bartenders AND the karaoke jockey extra tips when no special services are provided. Karaoke fans, go somewhere else for your night of fun.
author: Katrina D.

description: This place is fun and the drinks are cheap, too. You can definitely tell who the regulars are. There karaoke collection is pretty large. I just don't like that the songs are listed by title and not artist. I always find this to be harder to find what I am looking for.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Inebriated patrons singing and sometimes dancing with wanton abandon: gold.

Tip the KJ well and he'll move you up the list, else wait an hour.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Its a Karaoke dive-bar.  You can imagine what its like.  I felt like someone was going to start walking around asking for Keno bets at any moment because of the lounge-style furniture.  It's a good thing I like Karaoke, Keno, and dive-bars.  The drinks were inexpensive, the bathrooms were clean, and the patrons were friendly.

I had a great time with a bday party and if I'm in the area, I'll go back.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
I am so bummed to have to write this review, but hopefully management reads this and improves this place, because it could be super fantastic with some slight changes. 

First off...can we PLEASE get someone to vacuum and clean up a little bit? I get it, it's a dive...ENTER AT YOUR OWN RISK and yes, most of us are a little buzzed and wouldn't notice, but I was stone sober on Sunday when I went with my buddies for my besties birthday party and it was flat out disgusting. It's a shame really...come on management.... 

First off....in the ladies bathroom the toilet seat was completely knocked off and thrown on the ground. This was at 7pm on Sunday. Not ok and it was such a filthy experience to go in there. It gives me chills just thinking about it. Also, clean the whole bathroom...don't you have staff to do this? So nasty!!! 

The entire place needs an overhaul and the carpet is gross...rip it out and get something new...you get a lot of customers...come on! Or just vacuum for crying out loud. 

I go here because it's close to my house and I'm sure I'll be dragged back, but PLEASE SOS...clean this place up!!!! 

The CASH ONLY thing is pretty annoying too...my bank is not close by and I hate going to the ATM...again, this is not their fault, but what's wrong with allowing credit cards??? 

Also, the KJ here is kind of a dick. I understand...you get your song faster if you tip...I got it, but when we do...please don't be a dick. The security staff can be jerks too sometimes, but my bf finally got one to lighten up, which was very nice. 

The bartenders are rad...unless their busy then you never get a drink, but overall, the bar staff is pretty chill. 

We all ended up having fun despite my rant on cleanliness. I love this place, but please management....get off the bar stool and make it better so more peeps can enjoy their Sunday night here.
author: Tina C.

description:
I came to Encore last Friday night with a friend who was in town for Xmas.  We googled karaoke bars in SF (because I've been to The Mint & Silver Clouds way too many times).  We wanted fresh meat.  We not only had a great time, we said we'd be back.

Upon entering and showing our IDs, I got hit on by a guy shooting pool.  My kinda night.  I ordered two drinks for my friend & I, we chose a semi discreet table and sat down.  We're both a tad shy so we waited to put in our two songs, and guess what?  WE HAD TO WAIT.  DUH.  I wish we didn't wait so long to put them in but at least we both got to sing.  Anyway, I particularly enjoyed getting hit on all night by a guy who was much younger than me (I think he's a regular).  I even got to sing a second song before the bar closed.  (I sang Gin & Juice ... what a crowd pleaser!)

A few "facts" that I have read from other reviewers -- that I agree with, adding my opinion:
1. It's a dive bar. (If you're looking for class, why are you coming to sing karaoke?!)
2. The furniture looks like it's from the 70's.  (What exactly is your complaint?  Who really cares?  It's a dive!)
3. You have to wait a long time to get called to sing.  (Put your song in when you arrive.  By the time your song comes up, you have enough liquid courage to belt it out.  Makes it more fun, doesn't it?)
4. It's dirty (?).  (It's a karaoke dive bar in the TL.  What were you expecting?)
5. The drinks are cheap.  (Agree.  Also, I don't remember it being hard to get a drink.  In fact, we were treated with respect.)

So, in summation, this was my first visit to Encore and I will return with friends for fun in a dive karaoke bar.

TIP: Avoid "Debbie Downer" songs and sing something fun that gets the crowd on their feet.  I think the KJ is more likely to pick your song if you go that route.
author: Gina G.

description:
I thought a cat was literally being skinned while walking into here. 

To the bartender, we know you're in the business of selling drinks. You don't have to go to the mic to tell us that that is what is supporting the singing. 

While you're at it, can you go ahead and ban horrible obscure songs or ones from Jonas Brothers or Justin Bieber? Thanks. 

And for the love of gawd, please don't do the Yoko Ono @ MoMA 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7GMHl7bmlzw
author: Kenny L.

description:
There is something about kareoke that I enjoy... 

Is it the part where I'm doing fine until the middle when my voice suddenly cracks and everyone within earshot becomes tone deaf? 

Is it the part where I realize halfway through the song that I sing much better in the shower or when I'm blow drying my hair so that it drowns out the sound of my voice? 

Or is it the part where I sing the same song each and everytime, "All I Want For Christmas is You" by Mariah Carey, and everyone gets out of their chairs and screams, "OMGILOVETHISSONG AND IT'S NOT EVEN CHRISTMAS YET YAY!!", thus ensuring that no matter how bad I do they're too busy listening to themselves sing anyways?

I think it's safe to assume that realizing how bad I am halfway through is the reason I enjoy kareoke the most. It's humbling.

Despite the hour long wait, the books that smell like they are stored in a dirty toilet for 12 hours, or the cash-only bar with not so stiff drinks, the bartender and MC both have killer voices on them, and I'll be coming back here to sing Christmas songs in July. Don't hate, it's just how I roll.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Sober Karaoke

I cruised into Encore this Friday for some S.K.  Inside - I was met with an incredible rendition of All that Jazz by Jill K. Fong's great vocals with Wicked Games, Peter M with....Grace M with.....the list goes on......What?!!!!
 
Seriosuly now. What?!!!!!! I'm used to talentless Karaoke. This was anything but. No slurred words. No off keys. No embarrassing mike twirling. It was a solid line-up of Karaoke experts. Poised rock stars. Shizzle!

 I 'd already bragged to friends that I was going to do some sober singing (after wasted Mint moments)-, and so nervously (still secretly dreaming of the Karaoke star thing) -I submitted Otis Redding's "Dock of the Bay."

 As my song came closer and closer, and my throat hoarser and hoarser from all the sideline cheer-leading; I was tempted to pull an Ashlee Simpson and claim that I'd lost my voice. Instead I would seduce my 'adoring fans' with a couple of messed up jigs. But no true Karaoke-ers don't quit. They sing. And so I went up there (Peter M by my side (reluctantly :) )) and sang Redding on fast forward. I could see the words being lit up, and knew I was supposed to sing each yellow word - when orange, but my adrenalin kicked in. I became A red-headed Otis on Speed. Luckily some kind souls - resuced me on stage, slowed me down, and belted out the rest of the song beside me.

When the embarrassment was finally over, I awkwardly left to greet my two nameless fans. A blond woman who I'd pumped up for her upcoming number and a larger bearded man who actually was far more impressed with my side-kicks. But - whatever. Even when you're nervous and make an idiot out of yourself - be proud.  Because each wrong note,  just further convinces the timid person sitting in the shadows, that YES there are far worse people out there. 
 
 Buuuuuuuuut back to Encore. The moment I stepped inside I felt comfortable and at ease.  It's a large - yet cute space and the staff don't take themselves too seriously. That being said there were some slightly annoying hassles. First - they don't take credit cards and I reluctantly had to use their $2.00 charge ATM.  Secondly, you may be waiting awhile for your song to come up, and even when you ask the DJ when it might be on, he tells you a vague "between 1 and 10 more songs." And thirdly - it is HOT AS BALLS inside! Bring on the fans!

 Despite these hassles and some minor instances of  under-staffing  (the poor DJ guy - bussing glasses back and forth) the staff did a great job of getting everyone their drinks, and did so with smiles. With a room full of mostly buzzed Yelpers, blasting out classics - it's pretty hard not to have a good time.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I'm a hardcore karaoke fanatic who is also obsessed with finding the dirtiest of dive bars around. This place fits the bill and lives up to all the awesomeness dirty dive bars ought to.

The bathroom is ghastly horrendous, I will warn you of that. And with the cheap, strong drinks the bartenders are slingin' while you and your friends are up singin' (see what I did there?) you're sure to hit them up at least once. Do yourself a favor and bring some toilet seat covers and Purell. The sinks had no water pressure when I was there and bathrooms like this would inspire the likes of Pig Pen to wash up. But, the good news is once you drink a vodka tonic that is mostly vodka your inhibitions tend to lower somewhat.

The song selection was decent. I don't think anyone was left without a selection. But, I can't say the DJ was the friendliest guy (perhaps he forgot his Purell that night) but if you throw him a tip or two he'll find a way to get you on stage. And speaking of that, bring cash, this bar doesn't take plastic. 

Also, I was able to do an interpretive dance to two Journey songs, which was not only a plus for me but for the audience as well, I'm sure...
author: Kay T.

description:
Love karaoke, and have been here about seven times so far. Encore is not my favorite karaoke bar in the city by far, but it will do if you're in that part of town. Much prefer Festa, Bow Bow, Silver Cloud, and am looking forward to trying more.

Overall, divey atmosphere, decor and clientele. Drinks are kinda overpriced since they're a bit weak. Huge song selection, but it can take hours to get the chance to sing. Found the owner and bartender to be welcoming, and most of the patrons were friendly and supportive of those on stage. Bathrooms were pretty icky, though, and the whole place seemed grimy.

A word of advice: remember that this is TenderNob adjacent, and WATCH YOUR PURSES. Mine was stolen from a chair beside me when I wasn't paying close attention, and the police told me it's not the first time it's happened there. I understand why--I've subsequently been back and saw tons of women leave their purses unattended when they go on stage or go to the DJ to put song requests in. After the hell I went through getting locks changed at my home, office and car, it makes me shudder. 

Immediately after my purse was stolen, I did a quick look around under chairs and in the bathrooms to see if someone maybe grabbed the wallet and ditched the purse with the rest of the contents (keys, makeup, etc.). A bouncer even helped me look. However, a second bouncer started yelling at me to "Get the $%!# out" because it was closing time, despite the fact that I was in the midst of talking with the owner and writing down my contact info in case they found anything. Left a pretty bad taste in my mouth. Will only go back when others plan something here, but I'm never going to suggest it again.
author: Emma L.

description: The bartender was attentive and fast. Best part of the bar. The karaoke dj on the other hand can get over himself.
author: Brian H.

description: This is a horrible place if you are looking to karaoke. I waited 2.5 hours for an opportunity to sing and my name was never called yet people that came after me sang 3,4 times. This place is all about the money and the tips you give them to call your name. In my opinion this is a shady place that does not care about customer satisfaction but only money. I am so disappointed.
author: Camille P.

description:
Stanley K request :

Bad Company "Feel like making love"

Baby, when I think about you
I think about love
Darlin', don't live without you
And your love
If I had those golden dreams
Of my yesterdays
I would wrap you in the heaven
'till I'm dyin' on the way

Feel like makin'
Feel like makin' love
Feel like makin' love to you

Baby, if I think about you
I think about love
Darlin' if I live without you
I live without love
If I had the sun and moon
I would give you both night and day
Of satisfyn'

Feel like makin'
Feel like makin'love
Feel like makin love to you

And if I had those golden dreams
Of my yesterdays
I would wrap you in the heaven
'til I'm dyin' on the way

I'm no Paul Rodgers aka "the voice" but I can try tonight. 
"Feel like making love.....to you"
author: Stanley K.

description:
Fun Fun Fun. Bartender Tim pours a great Hendricks and tonic!
If you can't be good, be loud.  It's my motto when I'm having a cuddle or singing.
author: Kevin W.

description:
This marks my first karaoke experience in San Francisco. I passed by Pandora, but the need for a bouncer turned me off, so I read some reviews of this divey place up on the hill and decided to give it a chance.

It gets 2 stars because, well, there was absolutely nothing memorable about it.

Pros-
The space is fairly large. 
The karaoke book is pretty big.
That's about it.

Neutrals-
Bartenders were boring, uninspired.
KJ was boring, uninspired.
Bathroom was fucking disgusting. Like I doubt they clean it even once a week. Why is this a neutral and not a Con? Because it's a dive bar.

Cons-
I ordered a drink and got the bottom of the bottle. It ended up being a very short drink. The bartender charged me full-price, anyway. Bad move.
I don't know if this is a thing in SF at karaoke bars or what, but almost everyone going up to sing needed to surrounded by their goddamn entourage. Get a private room for that shit.
The sink didn't work in the disgusting bathroom. I don't care how divey you are, I want to wash my hands after using your facilities. I know I'm in like the 10% of men that do so, but damn. Get a working sink.
author: David G.

description:
How could I not give Encore 5 stars - I've worked here for the past two years!  I love my coworkers, I love our customers, and yo...I love to sing!

One Yelper commented on the buzzkilling 'Bridge Over Troubled Water' - yikes, that was prolly me.  Sorry, but you just wait missy - you ain't seen nothin' yet.  You'll be a fan once I break out my Manilow numbers.

We is the hottest spot north(west) of Havana...yo!
author: Mc Matty b.

description:
I do a lot of karaoke. A lot. About 4 years ago, Encore was my favorite karaoke den in the City. I didn't do karaoke as frequently then as I do now, but I when I did go out to sing, I really liked Encore. 

My, how the mighty have fallen. I go to Encore probably only about once every two months these days. The bartenders are super nice, and I have to say I have never once had bad service at the bar. Also, the song selection is good.

That's where the compliments end, however. For one thing, the place appears really unclean, and I don't recall that being the case back in 2007. Between the sticky karaoke books, tables that never seem to be wiped down and downright disgusting bathrooms, it can feel a little icky there.

Also, the KJ's seem to have a haphazard way of creating rotations for the singers. Sometimes they will rotate new singers in, other times new singers have to wait behind everyone in the queue, no matter how many times the others have sung. Sometimes (and I have personally witnessed this) some new singers will be rotated into the rotation while others are made to wait. Believe me, I understand that KJ's, in general, try to be fair, and by no means is this an "I had to wait too long for my song" complaint. I don't mind waiting my turn at all, even if it takes a long time. But please, Encore KJ's, be consistent and treat all your customers the same. And yes, as other reviewers have said, you should be ready to tip your KJ. That really appears not to be appreciated but required at Encore. I believe some of the bartenders also work as KJ's, but they are way better behind the bar.

Crowd control also is practically nonexistent at Encore. Even on nights when it's not really busy, you may have to deal with bad behavior by drunken jerks that the staff either cannot or chooses not to deal with.

I keep going back every so often hoping things will improve at Encore, but over the course of the last year and half, nothing has changed for the better. I'm giving them three stars as an average of the five stars I would have given them in 2007 and the two I feel they should get now.
author: Missy C.

description: Definitely my go-to place for karaoke, 7 days a week. Friendly staff, seriously potent drinks, and karaoke every night.  And half the afternoon! Fri, karaoke starts at 5, sat & sun, it starts at 4, all of which land you firmly in Happy hour territory & have usually have KJ lee on the decks! He brings in his own bonus track book, with up-to-the-minute tracks & obscure requests that aren't anywhere to be found in the regular book. Made of win!
author: Chef J.

description:
Let's go through a dive bar checklist, shall we?

Dirty. - Check.
Cash Only. - Check
Scary bathrooms. - Check
A vodka soda that's barely carbonated because it's really just a splash of soda in a glass of vodka. - Check

Ah yes, all the divey staples. But there karaoke to top it all off, so not only do you get to down a giant glass of vodka, you get the perfect opportunity to make an ass out of yourself too.
author: Hazel Q.

description: Super frustrated. I was just here as the first stop of the night, and the friends I was joining had been waiting a while at the bar already. I joined them to help order. After awhile a girl behind me asked if she could squeeze by to get a drink. I said sure! But mentioned I was hoping to order as well. She was surprised that we were still waiting.  It wasn't very busy.  I watched as everyone around me, and most after we arrived, were helped.  I checked my phone and 10 minutes had passed since I had been waiting at the bar. The girl who had squeezed in next to me was asked what she would like. While he was pouring for her,  I jumped in and said "excuse me, I've been waiting for a while." The bartender looked at me, and said "Be nice." I said sir, "I'm not sure what you mean because I'm being polite but I wanted to let you know that I've been waiting longer than others being helped and it's strange." He just kept saying, "be nice" and walked away. He came back and said, "I'm one of the owners" as though I should apologize. My friends tried to help explain that we had been waiting quite awhile but he just ignored them as well. This may be the first time I felt that I was truly discriminated against.  The fact that he was one of the owners was even more disappointing. I've served at bars and restaurants and that's just not professional or how the service industry works. So we went somewhere else. And looking through the other reviews on both Yelp and Google, it seems to be a common theme that patrons are having terrible interactions with the owner/bartender.
author: B P.

description:
Ascend the stairs to a medium-sized space, with a fully-stocked bar on the left, and slightly terraced floors to the right, for better view of the stage I suppose.  Lots of singers and lots of regulars.  Can be standing-room only during peak hours.  Be sure to get your song request in early, or you may wait upwards of an hour to sing.  The stage features a lot of space for you to get your whole group and dance.  When I came here, the Bay Area Flash Mob happened to have its members in tow, and picked almost every Madonna and Michael Jackson song to dance their numbers to.  Pretty entertaining.  

There's also a pool table in back for the less karaoke-inclined.
author: Gerald C.

description:
6:30pm: ZZZZZ!  (snoring like a fog-horn by the Bay)

Alarm Clock: RING, RING, RING RING!!

Matt (yawning growling like a bear): "OK, Rise and Shine, lets go to DYL @ the Encore."

7:30 pm: Matt went up the stairs of this Karaoke bar, and he saw only a few familiar Yelpers to start. You can tell that the party was off to a slow start. Many, who have seen Matt in previous parties, started greeting and hugging Matt with a condolescents and say,

"Hi Matt, I'm sorry to hear about Captain America. You have my deepest sympathy."

Matt whispered to his-self and said, "Yeah, Yeah, whatever!"

As the evening progresses, more Yelpers arrived, sing, also hugging Matt for the death of Captain America. One Yelper nearly hugged Matt so tight that Matt's circulation was messed-up that caused him to be a little nausea.  Matt formed his own "LIVE" talk-thread with friends, which happened to be the lone highlight from this party (if you wanna call it a party).  Other than the chat and catching up with Yelpers, this DYL party was very dull and lack of a spark-plug. Luckily there was another party that happened coincidently on the same night. So Matt and 3 other Yelpers formed our version of the Fantastic-4 and heads off to that party to try our luck there. Hey, Matt is bar-hopping. Imagine that!
author: Matt G.

description: First off, I would like to say that this is one of my first reviews. I have been in the industry for about 7 years now, and I always have an opinion despite my lack of expression. I am so enthralled by the service I received at this establishment, that I must inform the public! The bartender, bless his heart, made my friend an amazing bloody Mary at around 1 p.m.. I have never felt like more of an asshole in my life... With a quick witted and good hearted display of dissapointment upon me first ordering, he took his time to make a very involved cocktail. Not a note was missed. When bringing the drink back to the table, my group of bartenders were shocked! This place is an amythist. Good people, bad singing, and a caring bartender! What more could anyone ask for on a Wednesday night? My hat is off to you, sir, behind the bar with your striped hat! I will be back. Just kidding about the bad singing
author: Phillip T.

description:
I don't believe there could ever be a bad night at Encore - FACT!  My entourage of Halloween revelers bar hopped along Polk Street last night and after going through several establishments, we finally stayed at Encore for several hours.  The crowd there was just so awesome.  The karaoke stage area was packed with dancers.  The bathrooms were decent.  The drinks were ok.  It was nice and cool (compared to some other places that were just too hot).  But the vibe was totally excellent.  

For those who missed Encore last night, Borat sang the Kazakhstan National Anthem to the U.S. National Anthem.  It was awesome.
author: Olivia L.

description: Encore is by far my favorite karaoke bar in the City. If you're looking for a laid back karaoke bar that draws a good crowd, this is the place for you. The song book has a huge selection, the mix between the vocals and music is very good and the stage has enough room for you to work it. The staff ROCKS and Lee the KJ is very attentive and does a great job of making everyone feel welcomed before taking the stage. If you're a karaoke pro or still looking to rock the mic for the first time, I highly recommend Encore.
author: Dwight D.

description: This place is great. However, no beer on tap..sadness. On a good Thursday, the wait for the Karaoke is about an hour or so. who has time for that? It's a fun place tho, which is all that is needed for a girls night or night out on the town with your buddies. Overall a great experience
author: Zhenya T.

description:
Best Karaoke in SF, nicest staff, best vibe from both the regulars and first-time customers.  Yeah it's a dive bar...if you can't handle that, don't denigrate a five start dive bar with the best song selection and coolest vibe anywhere!  

Even if I didn't sing Karoke, (and I'm new at it), would go there, just to be in the presence of a classic dive bar with people who are happy to be there.

Classic SF experience, because it takes all kinds, and all kinds eventually somehow end up at Encore.

Plus, you can bring in food from a variety of 'hood establishments.  Best best--chicken (or veg.) shwarama's from Le Petit Marchet 1732 Polk St --open until 2 a.m.!   ...and no, I have no affiliation for Le Petit Marchet, FYI.

You rock Encore!!!
author: Ken H.

description:
Good times, got 3 songs in within a 2 and a half hour period, which is a long, damn time. I recommend submitting your song requests as soon as you get there, even before you get a drink, that is if you plan to come here on a Friday or Saturday night. I was here on Saturday night. Or if you don't want to wait, tip the KJ. KJ indeed as in killjoy! I wasn't very happy waiting for my turn when these mic hogs kept coming up on stage. I'm not sure if they're regular patrons or generous tippers, at least they kept the party crackin. 

And yes, "All I Want for Christmas" is always a crowd pleaser. Right when I got there someone was already singing "Last Christmas" so I had to jump right on it with my second choice Christmas song request. It's a good group of folks, a good time altogether. No need to worry about not being able to sing, that's not a problem here. Or you can just do a hip hop song, my friend and I killed it with some Salt-n-Pepa's "Shoop". There's a pretty good song selection, if you can get your hands on a book. Or you can go to the website and write your selection down ahead of time like a nerd. Shit I'm doing that next time, I had to throw elbows just to look at the damn song book. There was no Mint Condition-denied!

If you take a group of more than 6 peeps, you should get there early so you can claim a few of the tables, it's not that big of a place. They got a pool table too. I think I'll come back during the week or maybe I'll come back on a weekend and fork over a few extra bucks to the KJ so I can be a mic hog too.
author: Tatiana D.

description:
I finally made it to Encore. Being the Karaoke Queen that I am, this may amaze many.  I have to say I like this place. I was impressed with the abundant song selection and the numbered organization of songs in the books. You can choose by song title or artist. I think many places could aid singers by organizing songs by genre (i.e. Rock, Country, R&B... etc) 

The sound system is very good. You want to be able to hear your voice and the song clearly not muffled or tinny sounds.  The layout of the bar lounge helps. Having the KJ booth and speakers playing behind you as you sing aids the acoustics.  The dance floor is behind also so background singers and dancers have enough room to get down.

The layout and amount of monitors to read the lyrics rocks also. There is one screen on the microphone stand. Two TV screens to the right and one to the left. A singer can sufficiently dance rock out and do some turns and still catch the lyrics.

I liked the layout of the place and the old school lounge chairs and tables. Now the Restroom was alittle rank in smell and there was no beer on tap but other than that no complaints.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
YAY for encore karaoke!! spacious, loungey 70s feeling including cheap drinks, cutie-friendly bartenders and dj, pool table (for the wusses who say they 'can't' sing),  big stage (so you can sing and dance with yourself or with all your friends as back-up). huge songbooks, and each book categorizes them differently so you can find what you're searching for easily (although can be a challenge if you are indecisive). 

i la-la love this place!! i recently went here with a big group of friends and we all go to sing our hearts out (well, only the brave ones). go early cause it can get crowded but even still plenty of room and attentive bartenders.
author: Isabel C.

description:
Great song selection, friendly vibe, but  owner was going to charge me $40 to eat (and share) my Chinatown bday cake. WTF? Also, drinks were just ok .. No fresh ingredients (lime wedges were the size of my pinky tip).

No doubt I'll be back though as it was super fun.
author: Minnie P.

description: this place rules. i got to sing my favorite seal song and some girl did pushups. two thumbs up
author: James C.

description:
I feel pretty confident giving Encore three stars despite the small amount of time I spent in the venue.  The drinks were ridiculously expensive (averaging $7 for a simple cocktail before tip) for the venue.  I mean, if I'm drinking a rum and coke that's over $5 I would expect quicker, friendlier service (the bartender didn't acknowledge us for a good ten minutes, and there was some guy just standing behind the bar but not serving drinks) and a table that isn't sticky and lopsided. 

Encore has a HUGE songbook!  It was definitely the biggest one I've seen.  However, the fact that it is organized alphabetically by song title is a little irritating if you feel like letting your inner Britney out but aren't sure if it's pigtails-and-plaid Britney or sweaty-and-panting Britney.  

Apparently the only way to get your song up quicker, or at a reasonable time, is to tip the KJ $10 or over.  Yeah, that's kind of bullpucky (keepin it clean, kids!).  We tipped $5 when we put in our songs, and another $5 when we asked him to either push us forward or backward because we had to leave for about 45 minutes.  He said we'd be within the next 5 minutes, told us to stand by after the next FOUR acts, and a half hour later we left. 

What saved the experience from 2-starhood for me was the crowd.  Everyone is pumped, supportive, and having a blast.

Bottom line:  I might be back, I might not.  If you're in the neighborhood with time to kill and money to burn for a taste of the spotlight, go here.
author: Kellie T.

description: This place makes me smile just thinking about it. We walked by it and didn't even know it existed.. just off the busy Polk street nightlife. It is a total dive bar.. actually, it's below dive and into sketch territory LOL. But we did have a good time! I loved the cheesy Halloween decor hahaha. Their song book is super thick and has so many to choose from. You write down the song you want with your name, then hand it to the KJ. There wasn't too many people when we got there around 9:30 but later it got packed. The crowd was very diverse, lots of groups. It was a nice Friday night crowd, they would clap even if the singer was terrible (don't worry it's karaoke!). There's also a pool table. Drinks were good. Oh and they only take cash. Overall, not a bad neighborhood hangout.
author: Vol T.

description:
I love this place! They have a great selection of songs for Karaoke, the bar tenders are nice and the KJ is awesome. I like the layout and I like the fact that the Karaoke is set up like a stage. 

I met a bunch of fun people when I went here, which I really liked. I like the fact that the crowd is pretty young and fun. 

All in all, this is a pretty awesome bar to have a good time at.
author: Minoti V.

description:
I love karaoke. But I'm not serious about karaoke. It seems like this bar has a mix of people like myself (awesome), and people who are FOR REAL about karaoke, and subsequently hate the people like myself (who are, again, awesome.) 

The drinks are a little pricier than other places in the city, but pretty much in-line with other Polk Street prices. 

Other issues include the fact that there aren't really enough karaoke books to go around (they have 2), and the fact that the wait to sing on a Friday night is about an hour to an hour and half.
